params.note: Organoids and assembloids derived from human induced pluripotent stem (hiPS) cells model aspects of nervous system development and function, used to study neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders.
Human forebrain assembloids (hFA) were developed by integrating human cortical organoids (hCO) and human subpallial organoids (hSO) to study cortical interneuron migration and circuit integration.
hFA mirrors cellular behavior of neurons in the fetal forebrain and was used to investigate Timothy syndrome caused by CaV1.2 calcium channel mutations.
Mutant assembloids exhibited abnormal interneuron migratory saltations, and molecular analyses revealed underlying mechanisms.
An antisense oligonucleotide was designed and tested to correct aberrant exon usage caused by the mutation, mitigating interneuron migration defects.
Abnormalities in cortical γ-aminobutyric acid–releasing interneurons are linked to autism spectrum disorder and other neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs).
High prevalence of seizures and epilepsy in autism spectrum disorder and genetic studies identifying NDD-associated genes related to inhibitory signaling support this connection.
Linking specific genetic mutations to phases of human forebrain development remains challenging.
Pooled CRISPR–Cas9 genetic screening is a high-throughput approach to study gene functions in complex biological processes.
CRISPR–Cas9 screening had been applied to neural organoids for early neural differentiation but not for interneuron differentiation and migration.

Fig. 1 illustrates generation of hiPS cell–derived hCO and hSO to model forebrain development: coronal section of GW 18–20 human brain, differentiation schematic, and timeline for neural induction and patterning.
hCO differentiation timeline: d1 (DM, SB), d7 (EGF, FGF2), d26 (BDNF, NT3).
hSO differentiation timeline: d1 (DM, SB, XAV), d7 (EGF, FGF2, XAV), d13 (SAG), d26 (BDNF, NT3).
